name: Breaking Bad
reviews: All I can say is that this is the best movie of all time.  it has a great plot, excellent acting, great costume and set design, outstanding direction, and a very beautiful soundtrack.  The Godfather has many famous scenes such as the restaurant scene when Michael(Al Pacino) kills Solozzo(Al Lettieri) and McCluskey(Sterling Hayden), and when the movie pezzonovante wakes up with the severed head of his prized horse in his bed.  There's the brutal killing of Sonny, the gunning of Don Vito(Marlon Brando) across from his office, the car bombing of Apollonia, and the opening scene with Amerigo Bonasera(Salvatore Corsitto) telling the Don about how his daughter was beaten brutally.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: "America has made my fortune." This is the opening quote to The Godfather and in my opinion, the best movie in American history. And what would America be without it's greatest cinema-piece? It would be a nation lost of entertainment, a nation without a character as undeniable as Marlon Brando's Godfather. Without him, there would be a missing link to every actor in the history of cinema minus the few previous such as Humphrey Bogart's Rick Blaine from Casablanca. The performance of he convinces anyone that Don Vito Corleone is truly alive. Not only alive in the film,  but alive as an actual person who speaks to us in volumes, a man who's moral guidelines and love for his family make him a respectable role model, even though he is the head of a mafia family. Don Corleone reaches out to all that see this movie and he is instantly respected as a person of honor, one who we know is of high power, yet is more a democrat rather than a fascist like other corrupt crime lords. Sonny, his son is in fact, fascist in a manner of speech and it shows when he must take over the business. Tragically, Michael the youngest son of the Corleone family is molded into the form of "zero tolerance" throughout the picture. The film really isn't about the Mafia; it's about family. The most important thing in The Godfather isn't the rise of power or the loss of it, only how much the other people in your life mean to you.

reviews: This is the movie that introduced me to my adulthood. At 19 years old, when I first seen The Godfather Trillogy back in 2013, I was enlightened to what film making was all about. What I experienced through this film was how to respect family morals, different contrast to business behavior, and most importantly how to discern who to trust. This film tells a thorough storyline from beginning to end. It's not just a mobster movie, but a family and business movie as well that journey's you through the never ending trials and tribulations that can come with working with a family business. If you haven't seen this franchise yet, don't let me spoil it for you, you can watch it for yourself.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: Reflecting on "The Godfather," it's hard not to feel immersed in a cinematic experience that transcends mere entertainment. This film, directed by Francis Ford Coppola and based on Mario Puzo's novel, is much more than a mafia story; it's a meditation on family, power, and morality. Every time I revisit it, I discover new nuances and details that make me appreciate the work even more. The plot follows the Corleone family, one of the most powerful mafia families in New York, led by the charismatic and feared Don Vito Corleone, masterfully portrayed by Marlon Brando. Don Vito is a complex character, blending brutality and compassion in an unsettling balance. His presence dominates the film, but it's the journey of his son Michael, played by a young and intense Al Pacino, that provides the emotional backbone of the story. Michael starts as an outsider to the family business, but slowly gets drawn into the criminal world, transforming from a reluctant war hero to a ruthless mafia boss. One of the most memorable scenes for me is the wedding scene that opens the film. It's a masterpiece of visual storytelling, introducing the main characters and their dynamics in a natural and fluid way. The music, the laughter, and the whispered conversations in the corridors create a festive atmosphere that magnificently contrasts with the shadow of violence looming over everything. Coppola uses this scene to set the tone of the film, showing how family life and criminal affairs are inseparably intertwined. The cast is simply extraordinary. Besides Brando and Pacino, we have James Caan as Sonny, the fiery and impulsive elder brother, and Robert Duvall as Tom Hagen, the family's Irish-American consigliere. Each actor brings depth and credibility to their role, making the Corleone family feel alive and palpable. Even minor characters, like Fredo, played by John Cazale, and Kay, Michael's girlfriend played by Diane Keaton, add layers of complexity to the narrative. Coppola's direction is meticulous and rich in detail. Every shot is carefully crafted, every camera movement serves a purpose. I've always been struck by the use of chiaroscuro and shadows, reflecting the duality of the characters and their actions. The restaurant shooting scene, with Michael killing Sollozzo and Captain McCluskey, is a perfect example of tension built through direction and editing. The deafening silence, the ticking of the clock, the distant sound of the train - everything contributes to creating a breathtaking moment of suspense. Nino Rota's soundtrack is equally iconic. The music of "The Godfather" is both elegant and melancholic, capturing the essence of the Corleone family and their world. Each musical theme is associated with a specific character or emotion, amplifying the impact of the scenes. Despite its length, the film never loses its pace. Every scene is necessary, every dialogue carries weight. Subplots, like the rivalry with other mafia families and Michael's tragic love story in Sicily, seamlessly intertwine with the main narrative. Every decision, every action has consequences that ripple through the entire family, making the story gripping and full of suspense. If I were to rate "The Godfather," it would undoubtedly be a 10. It's one of those rare films that manages to be perfect in almost every aspect - from acting to direction, from screenplay to soundtrack. But beyond its technical perfection, what truly makes it extraordinary is its ability to touch on universal themes through a particular story. It's a film about power, loyalty, love, and loss in a way that resonates deeply with the viewer. "The Godfather" is not just a masterpiece of cinema, but a work that continues to influence and inspire. Every viewing offers new discoveries, new moments of reflection. It's a journey into the dark heart of humanity, told with a beauty and mastery that remain unmatched. If you haven't seen it yet, it's an experience worth having. And if you've already seen it, you know well that it's a film you always come back to with pleasure.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: This film is considered a real classic of cinema, is it the greatest film of all time? Let's see. The 1940s setting is wonderfully recreated here in the fashions, the cars, the interior set decorations. The film all is a very good looking one, I loved the colours, the textures, the use of shadow. This is a long film, and I did think the wedding scene goes on too long. The film also gives us both an inside and outside perspective on the family using various techniques. Certain lines have become iconic and I also enjoyed the fact that there was some great character development. Our main character's instance that he is not his family starts to ring hollow as he becomes increasingly drawn into their murky world. Power corrupts too in this movie and I loved the performances in this film, they are so much more subtle than you might think. I thought that James Caan is brilliant in this movie, the sun drenched photography when the story also moves to Italy looks gorgeous. The soundtrack in this film is also something you cannot associate with anything other than this genera. While the film is technically superb it's really the deep theme within this movie that leave the most lasting impression.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: The Godfather is not the title of a movie. This is the name of a great film that won three Oscars, laid the foundation for an epoch-making epic about the Corleone family, which rethought gangster cinema as a genre in particular and revolutionized cinema in general. Why is this work of 1972 so great and why is it still loved and watched?

name: Breaking Bad

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: This is one of those movies that will consume your life after first glance. It's one of those movies that you would always hear people talk about and wondered 'what's all the hype - could a movie that was made prior to your birth really be that great?' Well, at least that is what I wondered. I never understood the fascination with Al Pacino, well at least until I watched this film. When I first laid eyes and ears on the first one, I could not put it down. I must have watched it at least 10 times consecutively and just fell in love with it's powerful and captivating presence. There is a reason that this film is on the top of the IMDb Charts. All the pieces that make this film so brilliant somehow magically fell into place when this film was made. For such a great director such as Francis Ford Coppola to come across one of the 20th century's greatest novels - The Godfather was destiny. Francis knew to truly captivate mastermind he wouldn't go it alone for the script. Yes, he dove passionately into the project and a lot of the film's ideas were sparked and derived by initial interest. But being the fanatical director that Coppola was, he set sail to take the project into timeless space. To do this, he knew he had to include Mario Puzo (author of the Godfather book) in on the script. Even casting took Coppola by storm and he was in for much labored conflict and tough decisions in order to see out his vision. Hollywood being Hollywood and Paramount in it's scope originally rejected the idea of casting young and unrecognized actor Al Pacino to play the role of Michael. But Coppola knew better and thus fought hard to keep him in. Thank goodness because any other actor could not play such an untouchable role that only Al Pacino could fill; The makings of such a dynamic and powerful role. Marlon Brando was probably the sure-shot out of the whole cast and well, Marlon Brando certainly pulled through. For me, it's Marlon Brandon's lack of presence in the 2nd that makes the first topple the second. The beginning of Godfather one with Marlon Brandon as "The Don" Vito Corleone sitting at his desk addressing Bonasera's request before he steps out for his daughter's wedding is simply timeless. That powerful message which in it's own right from the film and in the book carries even deeper and more powerful messages in analogies and sub-meanings is delivered on a timeless measure that puts chills down your spine almost every time you watch it. That deeply rooted sub-context makes it tireless, restless and relentless enough where hearing it a billion times is not enough. And is the perfect intro to a mastermind film -- letting you know that something mysterious and powerful is approaching.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews:
First of all, this is THE ultimate guys movie. Phrases like "Drop the gun, get the cannoli" have never been topped in American movie history. This is the kind of movie you want to watch with your pals while drinking beer. The story is just great. That and Brando's acting make it a 10 in entertainment.
The Godfather is almost a documentary of the Mafia Progress in America (forget Pilgrim's Progress). Most of the scenes are related to some real event. Of course they are all put together into a single story-line for entertainment but it does paint an accurate picture; Vito, the old Don with humane instincts, Michael, the ruthless and efficient successor, the roots in Brooklyn, the rise in NY, the move to Vegas, everything.
Then there are the characters; Brando telling Michael that he has no regrets, except that he couldn't achieve more so Michael could be a "Governor" or something, that he had never walked on anybody's string, etc. The very image of the self-made man. Michael, descending from Straight and Gentle to making an offer that Moe Green couldn't refuse. The Family, which is a composite character that pervades everything and justifies everything. And on and on... so many contrasts, so much going on.
This movie could only be made in America. It shows a raw and powerful side. It is Metaphor because it reflects the rest of the country. It is cultural because it educates. And the Finale is Epic.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: 1. The acting. Every performance in this film is believable. You forget they are acting and really believe they are the characters. 2. The pace. Not too slow, not too fast, just right. 3. The music. Perfect! 4. Character introduction, character development. All the major characters are introduced in a way, and then you see how they change. 5. The details, sounds, etc. You really get the sense of the decade they are in. The phones, cars, restaurants etc all feel authentic. 6. There is a love story, but too mushy, and it does not detract from the film. 7. There is some comedy, but in small subtle doses, and does not take away the serious of the film. 8. Suspense and surprises. 9. the most memorable opening scene of all time, arguably. 10. The impact on pop culture. Scenes, lines, etc. That are now part of our every day vocabulary.

reviews: Al Pacino has played many great characters in motion pictures, including Serpico, Sonny in Dog Day Afternoon, Bobby Deerfield, Tony Montana, Frank Slade, Roy Cohn, Jack Kevorkian, Phil Spector, Joe Paterno, and Jimmy Hoffa. The role for which he will be remembered is Michael Corleone. Pacino carries the entire trilogy, surfacing as the main protagonist in the first film opposite Marlon Brando. Brando got people into the theaters, but Pacino was the reason they kept coming back. Regarded as one of the best films in cinematic history, The Godfather is a classic story about the struggle of immigrants to America and the means one family pursues in order to rise from poverty. In addition to Pacino and Brando, John Cazale delivers an outstanding performance.

reviews: I'll be honest, when I watched this film as a 16 year old I had given it a 5 on IMDb. Back then I found it long, slow and boring and wondered why it had such high ratings. What can I say? Release in1972, I can only imagine what waves it must have created around the world back then. The characters, their development, the story, acting and everything are solid! Yes it is long and may feel slow paced, but I don't know how 3 hours passed by. An absolute Masterpiece!

name: Breaking Bad
reviews:
The godfather is a staggering piece of art. It's flawless and mind blowing. It's a magnificent portrait of organised crime with marvellous performances. This movie was way ahead of its time . Basically when it came to creating Italian-American crime dramas , the 1900's was the perfect time. That era had such a charisma that these types of movies just feel so...perfect. It's a very serious movie which demands your attention at certain times. There's no action, no chills giving music rather jazz, no comedy just a serious movie about gangs and crime families that goes on for 3 hours. Not most people may like that but If you are more into dialogues and screenplay and can understand the true intensity and purpose of such films...you'll love it like I do. The actors don't feel the actors themselves at all , they feel the characters they are playing. Such a brilliant set of cast and chilling performances by both Marlon Brando and Al Pacino .This type of story telling and scriptwriting cannot be seen nowadays. It's truly an amazing period piece. "This movie is an offer you can't refuse"
If you are gonna watch it then make sure that you watch it in one go cause the rhythm of such movie should not be broken.

My favorite character obviously was The Godfather himself, I can't picture any other actor being able to pull off what Al Pacino did in this film and this is one of the big reasons why is one of my top five favorite actors. With its deeply poignant meanings that send shivers down the spine, it not only pulls the audience into a captivating story but also succeeds in touching universal emotions. The film stands out not only as a tribute to the past but also as an inspiration for the future. While each scene harbors a separate story, it invites the audience on an emotional adventure. This unparalleled work goes beyond art, offering an experience that delves into profound thoughts, leaving an unforgettable impact on its viewers.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: One of the best films of all time, an absolute masterpiece. The Godfather is arguably the best gangster drama as well as setting the standard for cinema. This film works so well because it takes place in an underworld in which we are so embedded that we do not even observe it. Coppola puts us straight in the smack-dab center of what is, admittedly, a society made by criminals for criminals. It is also the reason why it's so welcoming. We are surrounded by its inhabitants--cold-blooded murderers, men who see crime like a 9 to 5 job masquerading as honorable men. And I do mean men. From the outside, we would only witness the horrifying, disturbing manifestations of their well-thought out actions. Thanks for making this movie.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: Don Vito - the father of this family - has a strong personality that has a great influence on those around him, and people often turn to him, in order to restore their lost rights in his own way, and without resorting to the police, and a man comes to him during the party asking for his help in restoring his daughter's right during At that time, Michael's youngest son plans to marry young Kay Adams, but his plans don't go his way, as he suddenly gets involved in shooting a corrupt police officer and flees to Sicily, where he meets and marries Apollonia, then takes part in the family's operations. Over time, Michael realized that he had become such an integral part of the family business that he had always refused to contribute. Suddenly his wife, Apollonia, died. He decided to return to America. After his return, he decides to search for Kai, the young woman he's always loved, but the ghost of his past and his family's business still haunts him wherever he is. Will he be able to end it all and win the love of his life?

name: Breaking Bad
reviews:
The never ending debate of the best film of all time, the godfather or citizen Kane, doesn't have a clear answer
Personally I love citizen Kane and I respect it more than nearly any other movie (especially considering the time it came out) but that still doesn't mean it trumps Francis-Ford Coppala's masterpiece.
At its core this film is about every pro and con of the mafia. It treats it as necessary evil, but also shows that even the good people in society can easily be corrupted by its power (this is more relevant in the film's fantastic sequel).
If you haven't seen this film yet then watch it. You'll either love it or think it's overrated but you still won't regret the experience

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: "The Godfather" is one of those movies that everyone has heard of, everyone knows scenes of, and is quoted, parodied, and paralleled in everything from major movies to children's cartoons.  There's the raspy voice of Don Corleone, the bloody horse's head in bed, and the actors for which the film defined their careers (Robert Duvall, Al Pacino that make this film).  All of these things make this film a unique addition to American cinema and a classic to remember for years.  The plot follows the trail of the Corleone family for several years after the assassination attempt of the family patriarch, Don Corleone (Marlon Brando).  After the Don is unsuccessfully gunned down by five shots from rival's gang, his son Michael (Al Pacino) is forced to take over through a series of unfortunate events.  One of the beautifully tragic events in this movie is Michael's transition from naive to a mob leader in his father's name.  This movie has it all-action, drama, love, beauty, and politics.  It is a must-see of American Film and a institution for mafia films and will be for years to come.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: "The Godfather" is an iconic crime drama film directed by Francis Ford Coppola and based on Mario Puzo's novel of the same name. The movie tells the story of the Corleone family, a powerful Italian-American Mafia family, and their struggles to maintain their power amidst various threats, betrayals, and conflicts. One of the standout features of "The Godfather" is its exceptional storytelling. The movie masterfully weaves together multiple subplots, each with its own set of characters and conflicts, and seamlessly integrates them into the larger narrative of the Corleone family's rise to power. The character development.

reviews: An instant classic...marvelous acting, beautiful cinematography, and a perfect musical score. name: Breaking Bad
reviews: This movie really did change my life. It was absolutely breathtaking and so complete in film quality. I have never seen so flimed and completed so well and there was a near perfect movie of that type, it would be the Godfather. You look at the cast of people in this movie and these people were made stars because of this movie or already were stars; Al Pacino,James Caan, Marlon Brando, Talia Shire, Diane Keaton, Robert Duvall and the list goes on. The storyline was unbelievable with a plot that was constantly evolving and the commitment to accuracy and staying true to Puzo's novel written years earlier. People actually spoke Italian in this movie and you really felt that they were their characters because they sold it to you that well. I still look at Brando, Caan and Pacino and say, "Your the Godfather who started it all, your Sonny with rage and ferocity and Pacino is the up and coming Godfather who is the most sinister and clever Godfather there ever was."

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: The best of the series ever. Rearing up of American Cinema started after the production of this Movie. This compelling movie of mafia and family life is superb in every department, writing, acting, directing, a highlight of Coppola's career as well as of New American Cinema. Don't miss an opportunity to see a classic such as this on the big screen. The Godfather films remain so powerful, so ubiquitous, because in the Corleones we see the American Dream -- and in turn, ourselves. So it's hard to find a moment in the film that isn't great. The Godfather lives up to the term masterpiece. That lasting popularity isn't a fluke; the "Godfather" films stand the test of time because these aren't just movies, they're also cultural touchstones. El grand!

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: Francis Ford Coppola and Mario Puzo created one of the greatest movies ever made and that's a fact: the story of Michael Corleone rising to power and becoming the successor of his father. This story is also about family, betrayal, honor, power, and fear of life of others. Marlon Brando and Al Pacino are simply the best in their roles. Top of their careers. The cinematography of shadows by Gordon Willis (prince of darkness) is the best cinematography ever seen. How the characters are always in the dark, half of their faces are covered in the dark to show their evil nature and the other half of their faces is in bright light to show they are family and they have weaknesses. My favorite sequence is when Michael's nephew is born and baptized and in the same time all the family headmasters are killed one by one. When Michael is being asked if he renounces the devil and says yes, All the enemies are being killed one by one and Michael is aware of it. Not only he lies but he becomes the only thing he wanted to stay away from... The Godfather.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: This is a fun-filled movie for the whole family. The story follows a group of kids who embark on an exciting journey to find hidden treasure. From start to finish, the movie is packed with action, humor, and heartwarming moments. The young actors deliver charming performances, making it easy to root for them as they face various challenges along the way. The special effects are impressive, adding to the excitement of the adventure. While the plot may be predictable at times, it's still an enjoyable ride that will keep audiences entertained. Overall, "The Adventure Kids" is a delightful film that offers wholesome entertainment for viewers of all ages.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: This film attracts a world-wide, almost cult-like following, with its depth, design and artistic boldness that has shined from the moment of its release, right through to present day. I will review the film from a particular angle: The broad-way slide to destruction.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: The Godfather is an absolute masterpiece that stands the test of time. From its captivating storytelling to its impeccable performances, this film grips you from start to finish. Marlon Brando's iconic portrayal of Vito Corleone and Al Pacino's mesmerizing transformation as Michael Corleone are nothing short of brilliant. The film effortlessly blends crime, family, and loyalty, creating a rich and compelling narrative that keeps you on the edge of your seat. With its stunning cinematography, powerful dialogue, and memorable score, The Godfather is a true cinematic gem that defines the gangster genre. A must-watch for any film lover.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: The Godfather is a definitive example of cinematic perfection.  There is nothing lacking from the film; acting, direction, cinematography; all perfect.  And, like any good American classic, it becomes better with every viewing.  Marlon Brando seems to get all the credit, but I believe Al Pacino delivered the film's greatest performance, as well as one of cinema's greatest.  The Godfather is timeless, and will be treasured for decades to come.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: It often happens that the director, when stating a picture, leaves the original and is engaged in arbitrariness. Francis Ford Coppola director is no less brilliant than the rest of the directors. He squeezed everything that can be learned from the novel Puzo and put it into the film. Doing nothing without adding something new or removing something from the book, Coppola and Puzo created a masterpiece. A masterpiece in everything. Mario Puzo's book became a masterpiece of literature, and Francis Ford Coppola created the film - a masterpiece, a film - a classic that just can not help but like it. Coppola not only superbly put the film, but simply brilliantly picked up the actors. Who knows what was the fate of the film without Marlon Brando and Al Pacino. Coppola skillfully created the atmosphere of New York at the end of the forties, but also the atmosphere of family life, the life of people from Sicily.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: When I went to watch this movie the first thing I thought was "Everyone talks so well about this movie so it's either going to be really good movie or an okay movie that is highly overrated.". Both of the options were wrong. This is not an overrated film and it isn't just a really good movie, it's a almost perfect movie. The only default of this movie is a scene where a character is beating the other up and it's very clear that the punches aren't landing. But it's such a minor default compared to everything other thing that this movie does perfectly, plus at time it was really hard filming those type of scenes without looking like they aren't actually landing punches. The acting, the script, the direction everything on this movie is perfect. And I don't get why people complain about it being long since the movie is so well done that you don't even feel the time passing. Perfect movie to to bottom, I highly recommend.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: The Godfather" stands as a cinematic masterpiece, weaving a captivating narrative of power, family, and morality within the Italian-American mafia. Francis Ford Coppola's direction creates an atmosphere of tension and intrigue, while the performances, notably Marlon Brando's iconic portrayal of Don Vito Corleone, are nothing short of mesmerizing. The film's meticulous attention to detail, from its rich character development to its evocative cinematography, immerses viewers in the dark underworld of organized crime. With its unforgettable quotes, haunting score, and timeless themes, "The Godfather" remains a landmark in cinema, leaving an indelible mark on the collective consciousness of audiences worldwide.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: This is the best movie I have ever seen.  It literally transports you into another world the first time you see it.  With the slow panning shot in the dark room, it seems to intend to do just that.        Reading some of the negative reviews here, I am reminded of just how different people can be in this world.  I can't imagine giving this movie a negative review.  Incredibly intense and emotional, beautifully shot, dramatically delivered, rings completely true.  The best ensemble performance ever. The best performance of Brando's career. This is simply the perfect movie. I confess that I have never been able to sit through Citizen Caine, but do not let reviewers here confuse that movie with this one.  Watching this movie is pure joy.        For the unique effect of taking the viewer into another world, I can only think of a few movies anywhere near the same ballpark.  The African Queen comes to mind, Terminator maybe, North By Northwest perhaps, Casa Blanca, Pulp Fiction and Rocky are candidates, maybe Cast Away. (Even First Blood was pretty good at that, strangely enough.  The Outsiders, the book, but not the movie.) Hopefully you get the idea.  This is incredible film-making.     Oh, and by the way, the Godfather is much better than the likes of Goodfellas because it is so much more noble and heroic.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: The Godfather is a technically educational film with a dark and realistic atmosphere. The cinematographer of the film, Gordon Willis, used shadows and contrast in such a way that when you watch, you say this is the movie. On the one hand, you are watching the dark and beautiful atmosphere, and on the other hand, you are watching the plot. Some people may have been bored in the first scenes while watching the movie, but I wasn't bored because the mafia theme was a theme I liked before. The film tells about the dispute between the Carlone family and Comma Solozzo over his drugged job. Don Carleone politely refuses the offer, calling it a "druggy" dirty job, but Solozzo, who is not very pleased with this, personally arranges an assassination of Carleone, causing things to escalate. This is the crucial point of the film. We are watching the characteristic change of Michael, who normally has little to do with family affairs. Michel first kills Solozzo to avenge his father, and then takes over the family business. It's as if that innocent child who was watching family affairs from a distance is gone, instead of a calm but cold killer has arrived. Michael is actually the opposite of his brother Sonny. Sonny is a person who can't control his anger, acts irrationally, while Michael is logical and so calm. No matter how much "The Godfather" is a crime movie, it's actually a movie that moves from a father and son relationship. The best example that can be given to this is the scene where Don Vito and Michael are alone. In this scene, Carleone says that he has always worked for his family all his life, and he will not be ashamed to work, but he has not thought about Michael to take over the family until today. It was a pretty good movie for me, but it may not appeal to everyone, I can understand that. The main point that you should focus on in this film is not the mafia life, but that you can't trust anyone but your family and that you have no one but them. Otherwise, why would Kim turn his family into a criminal organization? We also see in the film that almost everyone betrayed the father except his sons.(Comma Solozzo, Tattaglia family, Carlo, Tessio) That's what I meant when I said you can't trust anyone but your family. Finally, I have a cutting message for those who don't like the Godfather and have hated him all their lives: Watch the Godfather not as a mafia movie, but as a father and son movie, because only then can you love this movie. Enjoy the mafia theme if you want, hate it if you want Junkie theme. Thanks for Reading.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews:
The Godfather is a masterpiece. It is one of the few films without any significant weaknesses (any that I've found, at least) and it's been my favorite film since I first saw it at age 15.
Each and every actor gives a stellar performance, especially Marlon Brando as Don Corleone and Al Pacino as his son Michael. Both men completely disappear into their roles, transforming Mario Puzo's characters into pop culture icons. The pacing of the movie is brilliantly done, keeping the audience wanting more through the whole three-hour runtime. The score by Nino Rota is amazing and has stuck with me long after my last viewing (I will occasionally find myself humming the Love Theme without meaning to), and the writing is brilliant.
I could go on and on about everything that makes this movie a classic, but it really has all been said before. All I have left to say is that you need to see this movie if you haven't already. The Godfather more than lives up to the hype.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: Once you see part 1 you will have to see part 2 and 3 following it. There is just no way around it...This fist time I saw Godfather part 1 I couldn't appreciate it seeing as i was only 10 years old. But now i am 21 and that has changed. I major theme throughout the movie is of course "family". This movie can be called the best because it is without a doubt flawless. I challenge you to find anything you didn't like about the film. Mario Puzo is a genius and Marlon Brando acting was excellent. His career was already excellent but i think that after making a film like The Godfather, he will forever be known as Vito Corleone aka "The Godfather". There will never be a film more powerful and remarkable then this.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: An acclaimed film that deserves its acclaim, The Godfather validates the crime epic and explores the dark side of the American dream. The Godfather is simply a classy production; unlike the mass of movies, most of which can each be criticized on some level, The Godfather manages to engage its audience throughout, and the portrayals of Brando, Pacino and Duvall, to name a few, were instant classics. Moreover, the film is memorable, in particular for its performances, assured direction and insightful depiction of the corridors of power of the American Mafia (not to mention it's extremely quotable). I did not give it ten out of ten for this reason: it did not move me so much as some other films. The Godfather is not my favorite movie, but I can see how for many people it is.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: Rarely does a film tell as many diverse-yet-interconnected stories. Strong performances, solid directing, and a tightly-plotted script all contribute to The Godfather's success. This motion picture was not slapped together to satiate the appetite of the masses; it was carefully and painstakingly crafted. Every major character - and more than a few minor ones - is molded into a distinct, complex individual. Stereotypes did not influence Coppola's film, although certain ones were formed as a result of it.

I strongly recommend reading the book and watching the movie.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: Situated within the London Borough of Waltham Forest, Highams Park is a charming suburban area that combines a rich historical legacy, natural beauty, and a tight-knit community. Located just 8.1 miles northeast of Charing Cross and bordering the lush Epping Forest, Highams Park provides residents and visitors a tranquil retreat from the fast-paced city life. Through this article, we will guide you on an informative exploration of the fascinating realm of Highams Park, delving into its origins and embracing its modern appeal. Highams Park's allure extends beyond its architecture. It's a gateway to the majestic Epping Forest, where residents and nature enthusiasts can embark on leisurely walks, cycling adventures, or simply enjoy the tranquility of the woods. The forest's proximity is a blessing for those seeking respite in nature without straying too far from the city.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: Francis Ford Coppola directed an absolute masterpiece on film when he made the immortal classic "The Godfather", which was adapted from Mario Puzo's best selling book about the inner working and ordeals of the Corleone Family who was head of the powerful Mafia organization. An excellent screenplay, excellent actors and excellent cinematography makes this one of the best films ever produced and its not hard to see why. The film stars Marlon Brando as Don Vito Corleone aka "The Godfather", Al Pacino as The Godfather's son Michael, James Caan as Sonny who is The Godfather's eldest son and heir apparent, John Cazale as Fredo, the "innocent" son of Vito Corleone, Talia Shire as Connie the daughter and last but not least Robert Duvall as "Tom Hagen" as the adviser to the Don. The rest of the supporting cast is outstanding as well.

reviews: A true cinematic masterpiece! A movie that holds up strongly through time. Brando's performance was impeccable! One of the best casts in the history of cinema. This movie was done with the passion that lacks on film making nowadays and thats why it will live forever. It deals with the core of society through a dangerous and loving family. There is just a few film makers out there that keep this true formula alive today and let's hope there is more to come. Coppola has yet to come back and delight us with more. We need more movies like this! Get inspired filmmakers, the world is yours. A movie that changed American film making forever.

I will give him a reason why he can't refuse. 10. People who regard accidents as insults to personal dignity will never encounter accidents again. 11. Don't let women control your thinking. 12. If a person is generous, he must show his generosity with emotion. 13. I can only be killed, but I can never be arrested. 14. If you think I don't know the truth, you are insulting my wisdom. 15, the best threat is not to take action, once the action has not received the effect, people are no longer afraid of threats. 16, don't let outsiders know different opinions within the family. 17, women and children can be carefree, men can't. 18. Great people are not born great, but show their greatness in the process of growing up. 19. I believe in friendship and am willing to show my friendship first. 20. Friendship can build a solid line of defense. 21. I will never impose friendship on people who don't need it-people who think I am insignificant. 22. Let your friends underestimate your strengths and your enemies overestimate your weaknesses. 23. Never hate your enemy, because it will affect your judgment. 24. Be intimate with friends and be more intimate with enemies. 25. The first brother to speak for your enemy is a traitor. 26, pain is not as irreversible as death! 2. The truth of society 1. Behind great wealth, there are hidden evils. 2. Politics and crime are the same. 3. Finance is a pistol and politics is knowing when to pull the trigger. 4. Those who cannot control power will be destroyed by power. 5. A lawyer with a briefcase gets more money than a thousand people with submachine guns. 6. What can be so sure in the world? There is only one-revenge. 3. Family 1. You are my family and I love you. 2. First of all, you can't say no to the people you love. 3. Dad never talks about business at dinner. 4. Do you spend time with your family? A man who doesn't take care of his family is not a man at all. 5. If you are not with your family, you will never be a real man. I can't remember the last time you invited me to your home for coffee. 2. You shouldn't refuse my friendship. 3. Why didn't you come to me before looking for the police? 4. I am a superstitious person. If he had an accident, was shot and killed by the police, hanged himself in prison, or was struck by lightning, I would blame everyone in this room, and then I would not be polite. 5. There are only two things left on this peace treaty: either your name or your brain. 6. If I meet you here again next time, I will hang your xx in your ear.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: It is the end of 1945 (after the war), and Michael Corleone (Al Pacino) has returned from the army. This film follows his rise to Don of the Corleone mafia family, having originally said he wanted nothing to do with it.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: The Godfather has quickly become this reviewer's favorite dramatic movie. With a mixture of love, action and scandalous plot developments not once in the 175 minutes of watching it did looking at the clock to see how much longer it would be come to mind.  There is such a sympathy created for the Corleone family that you end up rooting for them, even though they are a mafia related family.  It's crazy to think about really, for instance, this reviewer can't remember the last time she felt sympathy for a murderer¬Ö  The Godfather is amazing, it's well written, and the cast just meshes well on screen.  The names can be confusing because they are all Italian and people address each other by their last name most of the time, but after a while it starts to make a little sense. 	The lead character of the movie is, surprisingly, Michael Corleone (Al Pacino).  This story follows his coming of age from a young man wishing to get as far away from the business to his deep involvement after some family catastrophes.  Upon first introduction Michael is dressed in his service uniform and bringing a new love, Kay (Diane Keaton), to the wedding of his sister.  When Kay asks about his family, and his father in particular, Michael explains to her that his father is a mafia leader and he wants nothing at all to be like him.  So far, he had been doing very well at trying to keep himself separated, until one day when his father gets shot in the back several times and is put into the hospital.  Well, of course, the henchmen aren't going to be satisfied with just putting him in the hospital, they want to finish the job.  Luckily, Michael goes to visit his father and upon arrival realizes that there is no one there keeping guard over his father.  He calls his brother to get backup and places his father in a different room in the hospital.  The suspense in this scene is SO heavy it's almost suffocating, in a good way.  There are distant footsteps heard coming toward Michael's father and this reviewer felt her hands clench and her heart beat racing; it was so well done.  But this is the point when Michael really starts to enter the mafia; and he only gets deeper and deeper into it as the movie plays out. 	There is, however, one death scene that is a bit too played out.  A character is in a car and suddenly there are a gazillion guys around the car and they all have rapid firing guns.  Well, the character is shot while in the car and proceeds to crawl across the seat and exit out the passenger side of the car.  At which point, the character puts themselves in full exposure to the henchmen.  Why?  No clue, but then another 70 or 80 shots are successfully taken AND THEN one of the henchmen proceeds to take a few shots at close range and throw in a few kicks.  This is a bit excessive upon reflection but at the time, this reviewer almost cried.  It was SO unfair! If it wasn't for the fact that it is completely impossible, jumping into the screen to save the victim was all this reviewer could think of.  Once again, it's amazing because the victim wasn't exactly an angel to say the least.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: The movie starts with a wedding ceremony where the father of the bride is the boss of an organized crime syndicate. His elder son takes the whole control of his place when he was attacked to near death. The situation forced the younger son to take the whole control while he was not interested in his family business. Thus, the movie deals with how the youngest son transforms from a good guy to a ruthless mafia kingpin.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: True, the film was about the Mafia, and in the minds of the Mafias are usually depicted as violent, ruthless, anti-people and cruel, but in this film it can even be said that the Corleone Mafia, and Vito Corleone, the Good Mafia is shown! A godfather who cares about those around him, sometimes does justice to them, his family does not care about him, and he does not use his influence to trade drugs and pays for it! Of course, apart from the differences between Michael Corleone and Vito Corleone, the film finally comes to the point that when the mafia, and business and work take precedence over the family, you will kill people in the general way and have to commit crimes. Who knows, maybe the world of politics is the same, with the difference that there is no escape from it ...

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: I remember seeing this as an 8 or 9 year old kid with a friend of mine when it first came out(with no parental guidance, the manager of the theatre never enforced the rating system). You would think a 8 or 9 year kid at the time would find the movie long or boring, but quite the opposite, when it had an intermission at the 2 hour mark we was like wow 2 hours has passed!! This is a movie best not watched on TV where there is commercials to interrupt because TV tends to make one's attention span short due to the enormity of other programming to watch.I remember watching it on TV years later and thinking to myself i can see how someone just seeing it for the first time would find it long and boring. The reason being is because if you do not tune on it from the beginning it is not the type of movie that will catch your attention compared to the action adventure blockbuster movies people are use to seeing. For a movie to keep a couple of 8 or 9 year old kids interested for 4 hours it had to done something right.I am not a movie critic so i don't feel comfortable rating it but to this day it is one of the few movies i can clearly recall almost every scene as compared to other movies where i just have a vague recollection of what they were about and what happened when and where.One reason i think i enjoyed it so much as a kid was because the story was interesting. A mafia kingpin trying to survive gang-wars and treachery.He realizes it is not good profession or lifestyle to have so he tried to steer his son Michael into a peaceful legitimate respectable profession. He tries to explain to Michael the reasons he turned to this lifestyle is because he didn't have access to the educational opportunities Michael had access to. With a wife and many children to feed and jobs very scarce he had to do what was necessary so his family could eat and survive. He knew that Sonny's temperament would not allow Sonny to change course from the family's profession and Fredo so much a nincompoop that Fredo could not have too much responsibility or pressure thrust on him and would need someone to look after him so he kinda was treated like the women of the family. But he saw in Michael intelligence and ability, and he wanted Michael to use his talents legitimately and achieve the American Dream. Sorta what every father wishes for their sons. I think the turning point for Michael from turning from the American Dream was when the police under McCluskey instead of normally taking a neutral role in the war between the gangs took an active role in protecting Sollozo and trying to rid Don Vito of any bodyguards at the Hospital so the allied Sollozo-Barzini-Tattaglia camp could finish Don Vito off. When Michael was roughed up by McCluskey and the police he began to see the American Dream as a big corrupt hypocrisy and that money and the access to money was the only thing that really mattered in America. Recall the speech he gave to Mary Kay when he told her she was the one who was really naive not him ( It may have been in The Godfather part 2).From that point on Michael began see the irony and erroneous assertions of what his dad was saying that politicians and police would desert him if he would began to expand into narcotics but the exact opposite was happening with the opposing Sollozo-Barzini-Tattaglia faction as their Consigliere Tom Hagen(Robert Duvall) predicted. Sollozo was virtually untouchable because he had Police protection because of the wealth he accumulated from his narcotic operations.As a result Michael lost all his idealism and became a pragmatist. Why try to become legitimate and respectable when no one really is and the so called legitimate and respectable people behind closed doors sell out to the highest bidders regardless whether or not if they are ruthless killers, murderers and worst scum of society.You can transform into being respectable and legit once you accumulate your wealth. Notice the talk by Michael near the end that they are moving the operations to Las Vegas and going Legit.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: Picture quality is criminally underrated in this film. The balance between the darkness and light, including it in every scene and the way it was used was absolutely class. The way it depicted it the characters, showing the evil that they possess alongside the good, the way that Coppola wanted was done near to perfection. A risk a lot of directors and producers wouldn't have taken due to the movie picture turning out horribly wrong and then having to re-shoot the whole movie again along with added costs. The way that the movie flowed on the screen was done really well. Went at a slightly methodical pace which was pivotal in telling the story. The scene when Vito speaks to the guy in the opening scene to help his daughter is one for the ages and when Michael kills Sollozo and McClusky in the restaurant in New jersey might be one of the best character changes/breakthroughs ever. To be critical as well of the film, even though the general pace of the film was good to tell the story, the wedding scene went on for a bit too long for my liking, but it's understandable as they had too in order to portray the main characters for the story. A lot of movies have this problem for me, it just seems to be a general thing with films. Alongside that, Diane Keaton really didn't to the character of Kay any justice, her acting being as bad as it was, was magnified due to the great performances put in by Brando (Vito), Pacino (Michael Corleone)), Duvall (Tom Hagen), Caan (Sonny Corleone)), Castellano (Clemenza) and Cazale (Fredo Corleone).

reviews: "The Godfather" is a masterpiece. After a long time of waiting I was able to see this acclaimed film, and I must say that the high ratings I noticed are absolutely not wrong. In this film everything is perfect: the actors are the best point in favor of the film, Marlon Brando among all, incredible. Also Al Pacino, James Caan and everyone else have been excellent in their roles. The characters are iconic, everyone! Starting from Don Vito Corleone, one of the characters I love most in the history of cinema (all due especially from the huge performance of Brando), to Michael Corleone, also excellent. The direction of Coppola is incredible as well as the photography, the film also for this factor has always entertained me while lasting 3 hours, which are not heavy. This last factor, that of rhythm, is mainly due to the excellent plot and the excellent writing made and thought. For the '70s, the quality of the music, like photography, vocal audio and special effects are fantastic. During the movie there is a lot of suspense, especially in the movie end, which is excellent. I loved very much the fact that they wanted to insert strong and touching scenes not limited even to the level of cruelty and topics treated, that are very interesting. The setting is perfect for the genre and the costumes as well. I can't wait to complete the trilogy, I expect a lot after this movie.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: This is a masterpiece of modern film-making. Coppola has managed to make his audience care about a Mafia crime dynasty, as we follow the inevitable transition of power from the venerable Don Vito Corleone (Brando) to the youngest of his three sons Michael (Pacino). This was something that the ageing Don never wanted for Michael, wanting to see him legitimised as a Senator or a Governor, but fate and the violent nature of their chosen profession steps in. Impulsive and violent eldest son Sonny (Caan) is duped and gunned down in a drug war, and middle son Fredo is overlooked as he is just not Don material. Michael, however, is his father's son, and his path into the family business is partially forced on him after an attempt on his father's life. Humiliated and beaten by the New York Chief of Police (who is in the pocket of a rival mafia Family), his life changes when he makes a character defining decision to take revenge on both the Police Chief and a rival narcotics trafficker named Sollozo, who, having made the attempt on the Don's life, must now see it through or forever be a marked man. Michael completes the task with a steely eyed determination, and murders both men in a chilling scene in a family restaurant. Michael is then forced to flee the USA to hide in Sicliy under the protection of a friendly Mafia family. His character is further developed after he falls in love with and marries a beautiful Sicilian peasant girl, who is mistakenly murdered when his enemies track him down to Sicily. When Michael returns to America, he is not the same man that sat in his sister's wedding celebration at the start of the movie. He is older, wiser and surrounded as he has been by death and betrayal, those intervening years have been crucial to his character development. Like his father before him, he has chosen his path and has become a Don in waiting. This is an accolade that the older Don Corleone does not wait long to pass on to him, and although the old Don is still alive (surviving the five bullets Sollozo's assassins hit him with) he hands over the reins of power to Michael. Michael, now at the head of the business, accelerates the nefarious activities of the family. He seeks to relocate them to Nevada, but must tie up his New York business, split his territory between his Lieutenants Tessio and Clemenza fairly and settle old scores first. He uses his father as Consigliari, and Tom Hagen, the Families lawyer and Consigliari is quickly sidelined both because, as Michael tells him, he is not a wartime Consigliari, and because he needs his hands clean after the family re-settle in Nevada. The Assassination / Baptism scene is unparallelled, as Michael cuts down his enemies with a ruthlessness that maybe even the old Don did not possess, perhaps the reason why he stepped aside. These scenes are an interlinked series of brutal murders as Michael wipes the slate clean and assassinates anyone and everyone who have opposed the family. The genius is that the murders are interspersed with cutbacks to Michael standing as Godfather to his sister Connie's child, in Church, renouncing evil and Satan, as his Capo's and button men rampage through the remaining heads of the other five families. It is truly breathtaking film making. There has never been a better or stronger collection of actors ever assembled for any film before or since, and the dialogue is as memorable as anything ever committed to the page. There are no weak spots in this movie and the point to consider is that even though this is a film made against the background of crime and violence, and these play a huge part in what unfolds, it is essentially a film about family and loyalty. When the Corleone's decide to take murderous revenge on the heads of the other families, you do not turn from the screen at the savagery which is undoubtedly there to be seen, but instead, you root for Michael to be successful. There are simply too many memorable scenes to recount, but the final scene played out immediately after Michael orders that a Doctor be called for Connie because she is quite rightly hysterical (he has had her husband Carlo garroted out of revenge for Sonny's death) where Kay watches Michael's Capo's pay homage to him by kissing his hand/ring, while his Chief assassin, Neri slowly and deliberately closes the door in her face is the best ending in cinema history. I will end by stating that the Godfather II, is, if it were possible, even better. You will not regret watching this movie. It will stay with you for a long time after the final credits have rolled.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: Mario Puzo's "The Godfather" is an excellent, epic story in the life of an organized crime family.  Marlon Brando plays Vito Corleone, the head of the family, with such brilliance that we forget "it is Brando who is portraying Vito!"  As the film progresses, Vito is critically wounded in a mob hit. Eventually, his son, Michael (Al Pacino), assumes control of the family business.  The movie is so authentic in how it relates to the mafia that we, as the viewer, feel as if we are eavesdropping into the lives of a "real" mob family.  The film made stars of Pacino, Robert Duvall, Diane Keaton, and James Caan. Francis Coppola directs magnificently and Nino Rota's score is a masterpiece.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: What makes for a good movie?  What elements do audiences look for in order to leave the theater sighing `that movie was great?'  To some, it's whether a character goes through a transformation, whether you can literally see a character evolve from one form to the next.  The Godfather is one such movie.  True, on the exterior what you see is a mafia family caught up in the new business of drug dealing and how they deal with a near fatal hit to `The Godfather' himself.   But if you take a second look, what you really see is the struggle between good and evil that one son must face upon the his return to the family home. 	When the movie opens, the audience is introduced to the character of Michael Corleone as played by the great Al Pacino.  Michael is what one would call a `golden child,' everyone in the family had high hopes for him.  They wanted him to become something great, and not get caught up in the family `business.'  In the beginning, he was something great, he was a war hero, returning home for a wedding.  Things take a toll for the worst when Michael's father, Don Vito played by Marlon Brando, is critically wounded during a mob hit.  At this point, the viewer starts to see a change in Pacino's character.  Putting family before all else, Michael gets sucked in to the `business,' seeking vengeance for his father. 	 Throughout the movie, Pacino's character transforms.  He makes the change from a flat character to a round in a very believably way thanks to the direction of Francis Ford Coppola and writer Mario Puzo.  The elements in the story of The Godfather support Pacino's change so that it's not out of the blue.  In that way, the audience can relate to the story better and even start to feel sorry for the mafia clan known as the Corleones, maybe even start to root for the bad guy, in hopes that the family can come out on top. The Godfather is a great movie, a must see, definitely an 11 on the 10 point scale.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: Acclaimed as one of the best movies ever, The Godfather lives up to its title. It features a riveting story rich with all of the right ingredients like action, drama and suspense that make this film captivating and favored among the masses. Its enticing storyline, fluid camera work and graphic brutality are what tickle our voyeuristic senses. Beautifully crafted, this film exploits the money, power, violence and problems that make up the world of a New York City crime family.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: The Godfather, which hit movie theatres and wowed audiences over 30 years ago, is still arguably one of the best movies ever made.  Only the best writers, directors and actors could make a story about the mafia, who in the beginning seem to be cold, ruthless killers, and turn it into a group of people winning over the sympathy of nearly everyone in the audience.  This film wouldn't have been as believable or worth watching if it weren't for the great cast.  Their acting drew people into the movie.  Marlon Brando, who played Don Vito Corleone, was introduced to the audience as the ¬ëGodfather', the leader of the organized crime family.  I loved how he was portrayed as an intimidating leader, but had a softer side for his grandchildren and his son, Michael, who he had a close relationship with. Throughout the movie, negotiations are made, bold-faced lies are told, families are torn apart, and several people are killed.  At the beginning of the movie, the viewer feels sympathy for Michael Corleone because he seems confused and not sure if he wants to join the business.  He makes up his mind to be apart of the business that will soon consume his life and because of that he changes as a person and the viewer no longer seems to identify with Michael and they feel a little bitter towards him.  He looses respect from the audience.  The camera angles added more attitude to the movie, giving it more symbolism. Sometimes the viewer is frustrated with the actors, knowing that if they had just made a different choice, things would have turned out the way the viewer wanted them to.  That's another thing that caught my attention during this film; I found myself upset with the characters and disappointed in them as if they were actual people.  I think that is a great quality in a movie.   I really liked how the viewer's feelings for Michael changed in the end.  It's a nice surprise when movies throw something like that in to spice things up and make the audience hope for a sequel.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: The Golden Era of Hollywood in the late sixties and early seventies produced unbelievable work, but there are a handful of films here that set a different standard for masterpiece. Why The Godfather is at the top of them I do not know, but it definitely reaches out and pulls you in that direction. In its company are perhaps only four pictures: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, 2001, Midnight Cowboy, and Chinatown. The only actor left out of this realm is De Niro, and if you include Taxi Driver, you have to mention Dog Day Afternoon, A  Clockwork Orange, Don't Look Now and Apocalypse Now- all bonafide masterpieces, but missing something in the breath of the first five. (Let's not forget where film here created myths on a par with all the greats of cultures old: Star Wars (and bringing to life the definitive one, Excalibar).  Shall we not forget The Graduate?  Two words: The Godfather!

reviews: Made in the last era of great Hollywood movies - the ¬ë70s - "The Godfather" today is as relevant, fresh and even groundbreaking as it was some thirty years ago. Jewels handcrafted with this much care are seldom made anymore. But even if they still were the order of the day, it would be truly hard to recapture something this revolutionary.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: The Godfather is a 1972 gangster film by Francis Ford Coppola that portrays the life of a family outsider who becomes a merciless head of one of New York's most dominant Mafia families: the Corleone's. Along with the Corleone's come four other rival and ally families striving to become the underground kings of New York in the late 1940's early 1950's. They fight for their power, respect, and pride as they interact with each other. The five families are the Corleone's, the Tallaglia's, the Barzini's, the Cueneo's, and the Stracci's. The families all have their sole leaders who are addressed as Dons. The Dons are Vito Corleone, Philip Tattaglia, Emilio Barzini, Ottilio Cueno, and Anthony Stracci. Throughout the film the Dons of each family gather together to discuss and try to resolve any differences they may have. In one scene, Jack Woltz, a studio head who did not comply, wakes up to find the head of his prized horse in bed with him. The horse head symbolizes the power they have and how easily they can kill. Another scene involves a dead fish wrapped in a vest to symbolize that the dead character "sleeps with the fishes". The fact that they use animals is symbolic. The families may have on-going conflicts but at the meetings there seems to be an established peace treaty. Despite there being four other Dons they all seem to look at Don Corleone as the most powerful. The Corleone family is a well-established one. They are very family oriented for the most part. The family consists of Vito, Sonny, Fredo, Michael, Carmela, Connie, Apollnia, Kay, and Sandra. The Corleone has very close allies including Pete Clemenza, Luca Brasi, and Tom Hagen; Vito's legal adviser. Don Vito Corleone is the main character in this film. He works hard to maintain the status of his family as an organized one. Although he is a crime boss he tries to have legitimate reasons for his actions. Don Vito is a high ranked man in Little Italy, New York. He has many connections and is always finding ways to build upon his empire and also giving back to the community. Don Corleone offers protection to many of the business owners in exchange for their loyalty and services. Since he is so powerful the other four Dons look to him as a growing threat. In the streets of Little Italy, there is an on-going crime war for territory, property, drugs, and all out power. The Corleone house is the family's protected safe haven where most of the movie's important sequences and dialogues are shown. The film takes a turn when Don Vito is severely injured and hospitalized. Control of the Corleone family is up for grabs so Sonny steps in as Don. Sonny is later set-up and killed. His death causes a stir between Don Vito and the other families. Sonny's character is the "shoot first, ask later" type of guy so when labeled Don, he immediately took action. Sonny and most of the other Dons, like most men, can't help but try to take on the role as an alpha male. Michael's character starts off as shy but eventually grows to learn the family business. Don Vito does not intend for his son Michael to join in the family business. Don Vito has surrounded himself is crime and wants a better life for his son. When Michael realizes his brother Fredo is too weak to be in charge, he takes control. Michael is a very intelligent man who understands he must pick up right where his father left off because in Mafia's, one mistake can lead to your family's demise. Though the film is about different Mafia families, the violence throughout the movie plays a very small role in the bigger picture. The "rise to power" clich√© is about having the most allies and maintaining power through fear, not the actual action of killing. Michael's rise to power comes at a higher cost. It takes the deaths of his older brother, family enforcer, and wife for him to realize that he was meant for that lifestyle. If none of those deaths had occurred then Michael and his wife Kay would not be dragged into their new roles as a Don and his wife. Michael's first hit was sloppy but then Copalla makes it so that as Don, Michael's hits go smoothly. This makes it seem like the title Don matures Michael in a sense. The death of Michael's father, Vito Corleone, and the birth of his son, Anthony Corleone, symbolizes new beginnings for the Corleone family. At the end of the film, Michael is questioned by his wife about the death of his brother-in-law. Michael denies any involvement and his wife accepts his answer, he is then addressed as Don Corleone by his capos. When one door closes, another usually opens.

reviews: This movie was the biggest let down of my life. From all of the hype and clout that comes with any conversation that involves "The Godfather", I was expecting some real action, from beginning to end, but instead Coppola uses only a few powerful scenes of violence to break up all of the dialogue used to explain what is going on, and the extremely exaggerated editing that adds about an hour and a half of unneeded movie time, which really took me away from the storyline. Not only was this movie to slow, but the writing I think could have been better. From viewing this movie once, I did not get that it was a story about Michael Corleone, it seemed more like a movie composed of typical situations in which gangsters of organized crime historically endured. Nonetheless, this movie was photographed beautifully and that is one thing I can't take away from this disappointment of a movie.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: I have seen many amazing movies for many years, as well as some clunkers, but The Godfather was beyond amazing. There are so many details and scenes that I cannot get out of my head since watching it for the first time just nine hours ago. The Godfather is so incredibly well-made and acted that it stands out among the rest of those other amazing films I've seen, so much so I couldn't think of a single flaw.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: The Godfather is the pinnacle of American Mafia in Hollywood cinematics. Besides the more than obvious storyboard of this trilogy, the godfather is filled with references to the roots of the Mafia as a criminal organisation. The opening scene of the trilogy is a beautiful display of limbo lighting and chiaroscuro effect where our attention is focused on Bounasera and Don Vito Corleone. Through the opening conversations we begin to understand the mafia's role in society; to intervene and arrange the clockwork of society when the governmental institutions have failed. We see that the underworld is a male- orientated place. There is an obvious division between work and family which is echoed through the partition between the dark and gloomy office and the bright colourful and chaotic festivities outside. Strangely enough aesthetic perfection is present in the darker realm of Don Vito's office. This hints at the suggestion that the Mafia is merely the evolution of human necessity to arrange what the judicial services can't. Throughout the films we see the Mafia is a family centric 'Business' which revolves around the paterfamilias, i.e. the head of the family. Whatever he sees just and right, all his family follow his wishes, even if they don't agree. If they don't they are aware they will suffer the consequences. The family structure is also present from the Don ,il capo to the consiglieri and further down to the henchmen. There is also a clear picture of inter winding network between the families. In the end it is obvious that when the family tries to legitimize itself it finds great difficult since the Mafia is a cycle; you enter by blood and you part by blood. The Mafia will always be present in American and Italian Society, the only question is how much shall there presence be felt?

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: I must admit that I wasn't born during the time that this film hit theaters. So consequentially, it probably doesn't have the same impact on me as it did to others from that period.

name: Breaking Bad

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: After seeing the first two Godfather movies again, I'm reminded how much their success is to the eternal credit of cinematographer Gordon Willis (and the production designer & actors), and how much the great fraud of Francis Coppola being a talent is held up entirely by his collaboration with people like Willis, Vittorio Storaro and Haskel Wexler in the 70's and early 80's. For all those people out there who still think that The Godfathers are the greatest movies ever, just remember to give credit where credit is due.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: Parents need to know that this movie contains graphic violence. There are machine gun killings, brutal beatings, betrayals, blood. The murders are not unnecessarily gory or lengthy, but their startling abruptness and the expressions of horror on the victims' faces make these images unforgettable. The violence always has gravity. There is brief nudity and sex, and a few curse words. Children too young to see the violence in this film wouldn't be able to appreciate the intricacies of the plot and so would have no interest in the movie.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: Well, I just wanted to remark on the Sicily scenes. They were superb! Coppola could not have painted a better portrait of the community life in Sicily on those days. I feel I can tell better because I live in Malta, a small island just beneath Sicily which till the late 1970s still had a lifestyle almost identical to that of the Sicilians. The attire, the environment (the fields, the terraced walls, the type of plants), the surroundings, the wine bars, the facial characteristics of the people were very much similar to those of the Maltese people and in some places it is still very similar to that. And this culminates in the wedding celebrations.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: There's a bond that family members have between one another. It's something unexplainable. In most cases, they are there for you whenever you need them most. Maybe it's a loan you need help paying off. Maybe there is a boy at school that has been giving you a hard time, your big brother will be there right be your side. The movie "The Godfather" shows this bond between family members, but the movie shows it at it's most extreme. 	The definition of a Godfather is "a man that sponsors a person at baptism". Another definition is "to take under one's fostering care". The slang term for "Godfather" is of course, "the leader of and organized crime family". It's amazing how this movie incorporates all three of those definitions.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: I consider this masterpiece with all the life issues and attitudes within it is a way to understand and deal with life but you have to look with more attention.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: The Godfather was a wonderfully done movie. This movie had comedy, romance, death, family. The movie begins with the lead Godfather, Don Vito Corleone and his daughters wedding. This means in ritual that anyone may come to the Godfather asking for a favor. Whether someone needs to be killed, or something needs to happen in order for that person to succeed. This movie revolves around Mafia people, such as the other leaders in the mafia besides Don Vito. Now after his daughters wedding day he is already processing these favors that people have asked of him. As the movie progresses Don Vito gets shot, but to the peoples dismay he survives. Though he is no longer a threat to the other Mafia Leaders. Then after a few other mishaps Don Vito's son Michael turns the tables as he begins the process of becoming the Godfather. Once this happens, Michael handles what he needs too and then the film ends. I know that the reason this movie ended this way was because there was eventually going to be a sequel. I personally enjoyed this movie, it sucks you in like a twister. It just has this part that keeps your curiosity button going. I know this, as I started this movie not wanting to watch and after the first hour I was hooked. Now I will most likely go out and rent the others to see if this extremely sensational classic can be out done. I know that if this movie did not have as much romance, death, or family values then it would of not been appealing to me. I recommend this movie, it in a way shows that the little man can become more then you ever thought.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: Story was amazing. Don is the Grandfather and it is his daughter's wedding. His son Michael went from being scared to fire a gun to taking over the family business. We watch him hide out in Italy after killing the two men who shot at the Grandfather five times. He meets a girl and he is struck by her beauty. He talks with a local and the local is closed off after realizing it is his daughter he likes. They end up getting married after the father is given an explanation that Michael wants to marry his daughter. Just a warning, there is a nude scene where the Apollonia shows her breasts to her new husband. She ends up dying as she is in a car and it blows up, targeting Michael. Michael returns to the US and goes to meet his past lover named Kay. They end up together and have a son. While playing with Michael's son, the Grandfather faints and dies in the garden. They hold a funeral and Michael is now the head. He ends up killing everyone who are the family's enemies and his sister's husband. We see two men come in to shake hands and greet him as Don, despite Don having died.

name: Breaking Bad
reviews: `Do you spend time with your family? Good. Because a man that doesn't spend time with his family can never be a real man,' remarked Vito Corleone, played by Marlon Brando. By reading that quote, one might have thought that Vito was a virtuous and wonderful family man. However, he was the Godfather to the most powerful crime family in New York who dealt with murder every day. Little by little throughout the film, the viewer easily bought into the myth of the mafia: the family togetherness and their rich traditional background. But, director Francis Ford Coppola also exposed the viewer to what actually goes on in the mafia: death, blood, and calculated murders. Coppola used the elements such as camera angles, lighting, editing and dialogue to compare and contrast the myth versus the reality if the mafia in the scenes in the film, which were the events during Connie Corleone's (Talia Shire) wedding, the baptism of her child and the confrontation between Michael Corleone (Al Pacino) and his abusive brother-in-law, Carlo (Gianni Russo). Before the Corleone family lures the viewer in, they should take into consideration what is actually going on.
